Now, after 210 days, with 13000 km on the odometer of our motorcycle, and some unexpected losses (as a broken pc screen, and an accident, that didn't affect our wellbeing, but it made us spend our emergency cash to fix the motorcycle, and work on some mechanical issues).So we are on the need to ask for some support that will help us fullfill with 'The Colors of the South

¿POR QUÉ INDIEGOGO? / Why INDIEGOGO?
Seguros de que la cifra buscada en indiegogo no es para solventar el total de nuestros gastos, ya que continuaremos trabajando a lo largo de la ruta, acudimos a este medio por dos razones: la primera, queremos conseguir un lente gran angular (Lente Sigma 10-20mm F4-5.6) que tiene valor aproximado de $500 USD porque nos hemos encontrado en la necesidad de ampliar la vista a tantas cosas por capturar y a veces no es suficiente el equipo con el que contamos, y aunque es nuestra meta lograr la realización de ‘LOS COLORES DEL SUR’ con equipo promedio, adquirir este lente nos permitiría aumentar la calidad de nuestras imágenes, aprovechando así el impactante espacio que nos rodea; y la segunda, a lo largo de nuestro viaje por Bolivia tuvimos una serie de problemas mecánicos y el accidente mencionado anteriormente, que implicaron un gasto acelerado del ahorro de que teníamos. Ahora, entrando a los países con la gasolina más costosa (Brasil, Argentina, Uruguay y Chile) buscamos tener un respaldo.
De acuerdo a nuestra experiencia durante estos 7 meses y teniendo claro la forma en la que gastamos el dinero, concluimos que el mayor, y casi único gasto económico presentado es la gasolina, su precio en los diferentes países de Latinoamérica es muy irregular. Por galón (4 litros) desde $1,50 USD en Ecuador, hasta $6 USD en Brasil. Calculamos para la finalización de nuestro viaje, de acuerdo a que los precios se mantienen en línea aproximadamente, ($6 USD x galón) en los países restantes, un total aproximado de 20.000 km gastaría 73 tanques llenos, y da un total de $1.200 USD.
En ese órden de ideas, la forma en la que distribuiremos el dinero será entre adquirir el lente como prioridad y lo restante será nuestra reserva de gasolina. 

We are sure that the money we get in indiegogo isn’t for solving all our needs, and we’llcontinue working along the route. We came to this page for two reasons: first, we want toget a wide aperture lens a Sigma 10-20mm F4-5.6 that has a value of approximately.$500 USD. We feel in the need of making our view bigger, there’s so much things to showand sometimes our kit is not good enough to make it, although we want to make ‘TheColors of the South’ with basic equipment, getting this lens will make our quality higher.The second reason is because while we were in Bolivia we got some mechanical issues andthe accident we already mentioned, which forced us to spend our money. And now, we willbe riding into countries where the gas is the most expensive (Brazil, Argentina, Uruguayand Chile) we look for a support.
Based in our experience along this 7 months and knowing the way we spend money, we aresure that our higher cost is the gas, it’s value in South America is very irregular. Onegallon (4 liters) can go from $1,50 USD in Ecuador, to $6 USD in Brazil. We calculate forour travel’s financing, considering that the value keeps almost the same that in Brazil: witha approximate of 20.000 km for73 gallons. It will have a cost of $1.200 USD total.
Therefore, the way we use your donations will be, first, to buy the lens, and the rest for gasmoney.

 

INCENTIVOS / REWARDS
Como reconocimiento a las donaciones recibidas, serán entregadas fotografías digitales o impresas, camisetas del projecto, mención en los agradecimientos del libro o la copia de 'Los Colores del Sur'
Las recompensas que son enviadas tardarán algunos meses en ser recibidas ya que estando en la ruta no tenemos la facilidad para hacer envíos e impresiones. Y la publicación del libro, para quienes lo reciban, será en Junio de 2019.
-
The way we reward for your help will be with digital or printed pictures that you select, t-shirts of the project, your name mention on the credits of the book, or even the book itself.
The physical rewards will take some time because being in the route is very difficult for usto send deliveries and make good prints. And the publishing of the book will be on June of2019.

NUESTROS RETOS / OUR CHALLENGES

En la medida que avanzábamos más y más fuera de nuestra zona de confort encontramos todo tipo de cambios, el primero y más notorio las carreteras que hemos recorrido hasta el momento las cuales han representaron un gran reto, al enfrentarnos a todo tipo de terrenos, desde las amplias vías ecuatorianas, pasando por el inclemente desierto peruano hasta alcanzar mayores alturas rodeadas de nevados sometidos a granizo o lluvia, a pistas destapadas de un solo carril poniendo a prueba nuestra pericia para no dejar nada al azar, aprendiendo así a conocer la resistencia y alcances de nuestra fortaleza mental y física, recibiendo como mayor recompensa estar rodeados de los mejores paisajes, los mismos que hacen impensable la idea de dar marcha a atrás y así continuar capturando y acumulando en nuestro archivo las gamas de colores q se nos presentan
Aún más significativo ha sido para nosotros el reto de aprender a desenvolvernos entre las diferentes culturas, ya que si bien con la mayoría de pueblos compartimos el mismo lenguaje, en otros casos no, como el caso del altiplano peruano y boliviano donde muchos hablan quechua, hasta nuestra actual ubicación en Brasil donde se habla el portugués, y como no solamente nos interesa el simple acto de transitar por un lugar, si no de compartir de manera ávida un contexto social diferente que nos permita retratar adecuadamente las maneras en que una persona o una comunidad se desenvuelve, nos sobran las ganas de aprender el idioma para comunicarnos debidamente, como adecuar nuestra forma para relacionarnos de mejor manera, permitiéndonos entablar una estrecha relación que nos permite plasmar de manera más cercana la realidad de lo que nuestros sentidos perciben.
Consideramos como un desafío para la ejecución de nuestro proyecto la clase de equipos con los que contamos, ya que hay momentos en los que se hace necesario un lente de mayor amplitud y luminosidad que permita aprovechar de mejor manera entornos de poca luz y de poco espacio focal.
Equipos con los que contamos:
Cámara canon EOS T3, Lente 50 mm F 1.8, Lente zoom EFS 55 – 250 mm 1:4 – 5.6, Lente zoom EFS 18 – 55 mm 1:3.5 – 5.6, Cámara Gopro Hero 4

At the time that we go far away from our comfort zone, find all kind of changes, the firstand notorious are the roads that we go that have represent a big challenge. Starting withthe huge Ecuadorian highways, then the ruthless desert in Peru that guided us to the top ofsnowy peaks, riding on hailstorms and hard rain. We also got into one-way unpaved roads,all this make us prove our physic and mental resistance, getting the reward of enjoying thebest landscapes, the ones that made us think of the impossibility of going quitting. This waywe will attain all the color spectrum that passes in front of us.
The most meaningful thing for us has been the challenge of learning to delve into thedifferent cultures. On mostly of which our language is spoken, but in other places in Peru,Bolivia they speak Quechua, the traditional Inca language, and Portuguese in Brazil. Wedo not want just to get in and out of the places that we visit, but to explore in to the contextso we can truly capture the things that we get to discover.
Our photography kit: Camera CANON EOS T3, 50mm F1.8 Lens, 55 – 250mm 1:4 – 5.6 Zoom Lens EFS, 18-55mm 1:3.5 – 5.6 Zoom EFS Lens, Camera Gopro Hero 4.

GRACIAS / THANK YOU

Si no tienes la oportunidad de apoyar económicamente esta idea, puedes hacerlo compartiendo esta campaña a todos aquellos que conozcas y tengan interés en fomentar el desarrollo de este proyecto pensado con mucho cariño, en el que pesar de los retos que se nos presentan, contamos con el ímpetu para sacar adelante y exponer abiertamente las cualidades que conforman la biodiversidad en estas tierras del sur.
-
If you don’t have the opportunity to help on this Project with money, you can share thecampaign with everybody you know who may be interested. We think the on this Projectwith a lot of love and we are very happy of being in this point of it. We are sure that ourstrength will make us go through any challenge and finally show to you all the diversebeauty of South America’s countries.

story:
What We Do

Hella Positive Pin Up specializes in radically inclusive sexiness. We're crowd-funded so we can shoot for free, allowing anyone who wants to feel sexy and share their story to participate. We've been going full time for two years now, well over 100 sets shot and shared with our backers, and stories and images shared with the entire world. We've had people from all walks of life, different backgrounds and ethnicities and ages and sizes and genders and orientations, all showing off what makes them feel sexy in the hopes that more and more we can all learn to accept ourselves as beautiful. We don't need what conventional media tells us is hot.

What We Need & What You Get

This last year has been our best year yet, but we've also encountered a few hurdles recently. In October we purchased a fancy new camera and a professional battery powered lighting kit, spending about $6k that we had managed to squirrel away on side gigs. But the time has come to replace the laptop that we've been doing all our editing and retouching on as we spend 6+ months of the year on the road, as well as new hard drives to keep everything securely backed up, new memory cards, and a few other bits and bobs needed to keep everything running smoothly. All told, we just put $4000 on credit cards in the name of a more efficient and less stressful operation. It's not a huge sum of money, but it's enough for a company that operates on a shoestring budget. We're hoping to pay off that debt sooner rather than later, and that's where you come in.

We aren't asking for a hand out we don't need. We're lucky enough that we can afford to pay this bill if we have to. But it is a burden on a small company, and if we can get it paid of sooner we're more than happy to give you some sweet swag in exchange.

The Impact

Let's get transparent on the numbers here. HPP makes give or take $2200 a month from our backers. That money pays for travel expenses, website hosting and other services, and the living expenses of our owner (me, why did I write all this up to now in the 3rd person?) It's my job, and as it stands I still need the occasional side gig to get by. I can pay of this debt, slowly, but it's a very real impact on my livelihood. Every dollar we raise is one less I have to pay off, with interest, to keep this project going.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have dollars to give, believe me I get it. There's a lot you can still do to help though. Sharing this campaign is huge. Sharing the blog (http://hellapositivepinup.com) is huge, as the increased traffic will lead to more subscription pledges that will help keep the lights on for years to come. Sharing your favorite blog on social media and forums or telling people about this campaign are all incredibly meaningful and appreciated ways to help.

 

Thank you. I love you.

story:
Short Summary

This series is inspired by art from the middle ages as well as Pre-Raphaelite paintings set during that time. This series references real historical figures, iconography, and traditions of the times but is not based on 100% historical accuracy-it is my artistic interpretation.  

Here is a sample of a self portrait I shot in this vein in Paris, as a Joan of Arc figure, which gives you an idea what the work will look like:

 

This series combines my love of history with my appreciation of the subjects of the work who are all admirable individuals in their passions and vivid personalities. I want to with the images, empower them through them playing various characters of these times.

The intention is to create a body of work that will be turned into both an exhibition in Los Angeles, possibly also abroad, as well as a book that will be printed in limited edition.  

 

What I Need 

I have already started to get things together-I have my roundtrip plane tickets, a few clothing items, and a 3 rolls of expired medium format Agfa film (and non-expired Portra as back-up).

The funds I raise will be going towards:

Pre-production and production

  • the purchasing of early-late medieval era costumes for the shoot (for 10 subjects-includes ARMOUR, CHAINMAIL, CROWNS): $1,400 
  • room and board for 4 subjects and I in Yorkshire and Snowdonia: $400 
  • train/bus tickets to castle & church locations within the two areas: $300
  • entrance fees to locations (10 subjects): $100 
  • paying my subjects (10 total subjects, some of whom are traveling-for them, this would cover their train fare as well): $1,500 

Post production and onward

-processing and hi res scanning of 120mm film: $800

-printing, framing fine art prints for the photography exhibition: $3000

-printing of the books: $1000

Risks & Challenges

There is an inherent risk in making a passion project being shot in two foreign countries with a lot of moving pieces, which when complete I need to pitch to an art gallery to exhibit.

As an artist with a background since pursuing photography seriously in high school, with working 'guerilla style' and self financing my passion projects, I am used to finding solutions to challenges that I face when making this work, as well as knowing when to compromise. For example- if I do not raise the total I hope to raise I will certainly have to make compromises-whether it is having less images in the series or printing smaller for the exhibition. I am prepared to deal with these challenges if I end up facing them! 

Who is Tara Violet Niami?

Tara Violet Niami is a cinematographer and photographer based in Los Angeles. She holds a BFA in Fine Art Photography from Pratt Institute (Brooklyn) and an MFA in Cinematography from American Film Institute Conservatory (Los Angeles). Tara's photography has been nationally and internationally exhibited-most recently, in 2018 she had an exhibition of 10 years of self portraiture at The Lodge Gallery. She just wrapped production as a cinematographer on the independent feature film Eye Without A Face, a psychological thriller/horror film currently in post. 

As an artist across the mediums she works in, Tara has a love of the darkly psychological, melancholic, Gothic, and Romantic.

Who Are Some of The Subjects of The Series?

Eleanor Hardwick

Eleanor Hardwick is a photographer and director born in 1993 and currently based in London.

They have exhibited in London, Paris, Tokyo, LA, Oxford, Lisbon and Brighton, at galleries including Palais De Tokyo, The Southbank Centre and The Cob Gallery, and have also done talks for Oxford and Cambridge University.

They have been interviewed and featured by publications including Dazed, i-D, BBC Radio 4, British Vogue, The Guardian, The Huffington Post, The British Journal Of Photography and The Independent.

Maxine "Cherrie" Sibanda

Maxine Sibanda is a filmmaker and recent graduate of the University of York. Her thesis film Porcelain Cradle which "follows Leto, a neurotic spinster with a depraved lust for love who dreams of having the perfect nuclear family, she is unable to control her compulsions and spirals into a state of delirium.

[The] story hopes to examine (and maybe even challenge) how blackness and internal conflict, particularly with women, is dealt with in the horror genre." (from fundraising campaign).  

She has also made the interactive documentary short Venus Noire and the short The Devil in Mary.

You can read more about her work and process here.

-

and there are more!

The Impact

I’ve also been fascinated myself by knights and princes, but wished there was more representation in medieval art of those existing outside of the gender binary in positions of power or women in typically “masculine” roles in medieval art. For example, women are often delegated to the love interest of a strong heroic man and without regard to their own strength and individual personality. Those depicted as strong willed were often met with unfortunate ends (think of Mary Queen of Scots and Joan of Arc).

In the historical research I’ve already been doing, I’ve discovered there have been gay and lesbian stories was in the middle ages which were erased from the art of the times due to censorship-for example, the story of the “girl king”, queen Christina of Sweden who was involved in a relationship with another woman Ebba Sparre. This project will in using the visual language and settings of the past, shed light on the present with how society defines gender and gender roles.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Share the campaign on your social media. Tell your friends, family, and partners about it.

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word! Share the campaign on your social media. Tell your friends, family, and partners about it.

story:
ABOUT ME
My name is Alessandro Zanoni, and I am a visual designer and photographer based in Milan.

Follow me on Instagram
Follow me on Facebook
Website


FOREWORD
In the late summer of 2016, I spent six weeks in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, making photos to document the transformation process of the most important cities in the region: Ordos, Hohhot, and Baotou. Surprisingly, these images recalled me the post second world war Italian film season that wished to raise awareness on the booming developments surrounding the historic cities of Italy.

The shocking similarity between images made over 50 years away, testify to a dominant, globalized and normalized character of these settlement processes. There is a common denominator, which seems to cancel the geography and the temporal distance between the events told by my visual-journey. The gaze moves in silent and mysterious places that seem to push the viewer beyond the empirical evidence towards an almost dreamlike dimension. Or a "post dream" scenario.


THE BOOK
During my journey in the Inner Mongolia region, I discovered that no matter the scale, the definition of habitat tends to be homologated. What I was experiencing, was the impact of the present geological era, the Anthropocene, where landscape, as well as earth system processes and dynamics, are altered by humans. The question posed by the project is if there is still space for another image of the city, beyond the apocalyptic dystopia laid ahead by the great metropolis of the twenty-first century.

It is no surprise the abrupt acceleration that urbanism has achieved at the beginning of the new millennium. The post-war urbanization responded to the need for real house policies in an increasingly industrial society that was huddled at the gates of ancient cities. What we observe in China, on the other hand, is a projection of needs not entirely expected, which foreshadow the construction of a priori housing complexes often empty. This is why the few people we see appear to us more like mannequins, or puppets of a show that got out of hand, victims like mythological shadows of a stage from whose destiny they are excluded.


My wish is to stimulate to an historical thinking, in order not to be dazzled in the future by the easy clamor of an inexistent present, and therefore to position our gaze in a critical perspective as when photography becomes a project.

 

BOOK DETAILS
Edition: 150 signed and numbered copies
Extent: 104 pages, excluding cover
Texts: Marco Bertozzi, Elena Rapisardi, Chen Liu
Language: English and Mandarin
Size: 33 cm x 22 cm [13 inches x 8.7 inches]
Printing on Tatami white 150 gr
Finishing: Thread Sewn, Bodonian Binding
Cover: Fedrigoni Materica 720 gr

story: ..

Help me make my passion for Ancient Egypt a living reality!

For years now I have read their literature, both funerary and for the living, and I do ritual re-enactment, for my own piety and for public involvement.  I have presented many workshops about magical practices and moral teachings based on ancient egyptian literature and inscriptions.  

In 2015 I had the opportunity to go to Tel er-Ruba, the ancient site of Mendes, to excavate and become the dig's photographer and digital photogrammetry specialist! 

There is so much work that needs to be done at Mendes.  Mendes is rich with history!  It has an ancient port with who knows what findings lie in waiting there, the Hill of Bones from which I have been told is a massive grave of Graco/Roman remains, Temple S which is the thesis work of Aliza Fatima, the giant free standing Naos that needs restoration and TLC and who knows what else lies enveloped in the sands of time at Tel er-Ruba.  The Mendes 2016 expedition will be an exciting one!  
Using photogrammetry techniques and collating data from hands on methods and plugging all that information into software we plan on a 3D reconstruction of Mendes of what it might have looked like when it was alive in ancient times.  Piece by piece, structure by structure, a 3D model will be created.  For this task we will use air borne drones for an eagle eye view of the landscape and its existing foundations and build up from there.

I have a chance to be a part of making Mendes' history come to life again!  But this is where I need your help.  The cost of my photography equipment with its protective cases, flight and meager living expenses while staying at the dig house, is not something I can afford as I am a single parent on a sole income.  With your help I can continue to return to Mendes and contribute to the research being done as well as launch my career as an independent researcher and digital expert in Egyptology!


If I am not able to reach my goal then I would have to join the expedition at some later time with your contributions being saved for that purpose.


In the meantime, with your gift you will receive at the end of the dig season handmade crafts and memorabilia from Egypt as my gratitude for your generous contribution.  For those who give a sizeable sum I will reenact for them exciting segments from the Tale of Sinuhe live on SKYPE! 

For those who would like to help in other ways please share this campaign with your friends and family on Facebook and Twitter or by using the Indiegogo share tools below.  


Please visit my page for future updates on how my campaign progress is going and my time in Egypt.

Ankh Wedja Seneb!
Life Prosperity and Health Everyone!
story_txt:
Help me make my passion for Ancient Egypt a living reality!For years now I have read their literature, both funerary and for the living, and I do ritual re-enactment, for my own piety and for public involvement.  I have presented many workshops about magical practices and moral teachings based on ancient egyptian literature and inscriptions.  In 2015 I had the opportunity to go to Tel er-Ruba, the ancient site of Mendes, to excavate and become the dig's photographer and digital photogrammetry specialist! 


There is so much work that needs to be done at Mendes.  Mendes is rich with history!  It has an ancient port with who knows what findings lie in waiting there, the Hill of Bones from which I have been told is a massive grave of Graco/Roman remains, Temple S which is the thesis work of Aliza Fatima, the giant free standing Naos that needs restoration and TLC and who knows what else lies enveloped in the sands of time at Tel er-Ruba.  The Mendes 2016 expedition will be an exciting one!

story:
***Please make sure to select a perk before contributing. Thanks!


Photohive is my latest labor of love

Photohive will be a student centered photographic non profit enabling students from across the country to propose solo exhibitions, participate in themed group exhibitions, curate a group student exhibition as well as lecture about their photography. 

I've been teaching photography since 2007 after completing my MFA at Parsons in New York. I experienced first hand the challenge of finding my first exhibition outside the academic setting. I felt frustrated having to compete with emerging photographers/artists for the same few slots galleries, museums and non profits offered yearly. Now as a professor, I witness my students' frustrations in trying to find exhibitions and funding to help participate in their first exhibition.

Photohive will be dedicated to exhibiting high quality student work while financially suppoting students in their endeavors to produce, print and ship their artwork to our gallery space through awards and scholarships.

Photohive will also offer semester long internships for college credit.


Why San Antonio, Texas??

San Antonio is the 7th largest city in America. I know shocking–yet we have no dedicated photography gallery space albeit profit or non profit. Additionally, San Antonio is home to Fotoseptiembre an annual festival showcasing international, national and local photography talent. Although the events are well attended we still lack a main gathering location to host and promote this event and all photography related exhibitions throughout the city.

Furthermore, San Antonio offers photography degrees and photo courses from institutions such as Trinity University, Incarnate Word University, UTSA, Southwest School of Art, SAC, Our Lady of the Lake, The Art Institute of San Antonio to name but a few. Texas State is 40 minutes away, UT Austin an hour and other smaller colleges near by which could all benefit from Photohive's existence.

Additionally Photohive could collaborate with the Austin Center for Photography which I co-founded in 2008 and the Houston Center for Photography on special events.


Board Members

Sarah Sudhoff — President, Tresurer and Director

Sarah Sudhoff is the founder of Photohive. Ms. Sudhoff is currently a full time faculty member at the Art Instutute of San Antonio. Previously Sudhoff taught at Trinity University, the University of Texas at Austin, Stephen F. Austin State University and the Houston Center for Photography. In 2008 Ms. Sudhoff helped form the Austin Center for Photography,  a 501(c)(3) photographic organization based in Austin, Texas and served on the board and as programming co-chair until 2011. Ms. Sudhoff earned a Bachelor of Journalism degree from the University of Texas at Austin in 1999 and a Master of Fine Arts in Photography from Parsons the New School for Design in 2006. 


Nancy Cavender-Garcia — Vice President

Nancy Cavender-Garcia currently teaches as full time faculty at The Art Institute of San Antonio in San Antonio, Texas.  Previously she taught at The Southwest School of Art, The University of the Incarnate Word, ADCAP program, San Antonio Community College and The University of New Mexico.  She also works with the Green Spaces Alliance of South Texas instructing youth in the art of photography. Mrs. Cavendar-Garcia earned a Master of Fine Art at The University New Mexico in Art Studio with a concentration in Photography. 


Libby Rowe — Secretary

Libby Rowe is the Area Head of Photography and an Assistant Professor of Art at the University of Texas at San Antonio.  She has been an advocate for the students' active participation in their own photographic education and she served on the South Central regional board for The Society for Photographic Education for 6 years and continues to be active in their programming.  Ms. Rowe received her BFA from The University of Northern Iowa in 1993 and her MFA from Syracuse University in 1996.


What your support will fund

  • 501c3 application filing fee   
  • Gallery space rent for one year
  • Library
  • Two $500 grants for students awarded a solo exhibition
  • Two $500 grants for curators to fulfill their vision
  • Two $500 grants divided among group show participants
  • Insurance
  • Basic office furniture and supplies
  • Website and domain hosting
  • Printing of promotional material                                                                                                                                                                              

Other ways to show your support

We will gladly accept a photography book or monograph for the library or a photographic print to help raise funds now or in the future. Contact me directly at photohivesa@gmail.com  


Visit Us

Please visit our website at photohive.org and join our mailing list for updates on forthcoming exhibitions and lectures.

Website and domain hosting
Printing of promotional material

Visit Us

story:
Short Summary

As most of you know, I love taking pictures. And, as it turns out, I’m pretty good at it. In fact, I’ve started building a base of clients who like my pictures enough to pay for them.

The more work I get, the more I learn about photography; and the more I learn, the more I know that I want to be a professional photographer.

A professional photographer needs a professional camera. I know it sounds simple, but there’s a little thing called “money” that’s been standing in the way of getting the camera I should be using.

That’s why I’m coming to you — my family and friends, people who know me and love me and want to see me succeed — to support me in making a career out of my passion.

Exactly What I Need

The camera I need is a Nikon D90 12-Megapixel Digital SLR Camera with 18-105mm DX VR Lens (see photo above), as well as certain essential accessories. Here is the complete list, along with their prices:

Camera body ($1,100)

Accessories:
Nikon 55-200mm f/4 5.6G ED-IF AF-S Camera Lens w/ Vibration Reduction ($300)
Nikon SB-400 AF Speedlight Unit ($120)
Spare Nikon EN-EL3E Rechargeable Li-Ion Battery ($45)
Vidpro STU-25 Camera Bag ($20)
Davis & Sanford Vista Fusion Tripod (Black) ($35)
SanDisk 8GB Ultra Secure Digital (SD) Memory Card ($14)
Multi-Optical Cleaner Kit ($16)
Adobe Photoshop Lightroom ($150)

This camera is lightweight and very user-friendly, with both manual and auto modes as well as HD video. I’ve worked with other cameras and this one just feels “right”.

What You Get for Helping Me

Aside from my deep gratitude, I will gladly offer a high-resolution photo that you can use to present yourself or promote your business!

If I don’t reach my entire goal, your contribution will still be put to good use: I'll purchase as much as I can with what I have, and will continue to work toward obtaining the rest.

Other Ways You Can Help

You might not have money to give, but here are some other ways you can help me reach my career goals:

  • Please help me get the word out by sharing my campaign with your circle of friends. (Using the Indiegogo share tools makes it really easy!)
  • When I do get my camera, please keep me in mind for any projects for which you’ll need a photographer.

Thank you in advance!!!

Check out some of my work at:
http://www.behance.net/gallery/Flashy-Liberty/5911845

http://syncomswebsite.s3.amazonaws.com/users/pr...

Here's What a Few Clients Have to Say

“Yesenia Ganan’s photos and video footage really bring out the excitement and energy of our live performances. She has taken our visibility to a whole new level.”
– Charanga Soleil (http://www.reverbnation.com/charangasoleil)

story:
Allambie Orphanage

My name is Mark Young and I am a professional portrait photographer who has a studio in Mackay, Queensland, but my passion and long term goal is Travel Photography. I spent many years in business and finally went full time with my photography in May 2013.  I first went to Vietnam in December 2012 for a photographic holiday and  I met many wonderful people and am going back in 2014.  Vietnam is an incredibly poor country and I was thinking about doing something to help while I am there.

I came across Allambie Orphanage run by Suzanne Hook and decided this was going to be my project - Allambie only has 6 children and Suzanne has funded it by selling her home and everything she owned.  Suzanne needs our help to continue doing the wonderful work she has been doing for 3 years now.

I am going to spend 2 - 3 months in Vietnam (depending on funding) and while I am there I am going to be teaching photography skills to the orphans and setting them up with cameras, computers, website (so they can sell their photographs) and ongoing support.  This is something I can contribute to enhance the lives of those less fortunate than most.

When Suzanne took these children in they were nearly starving, had no hope and some didn't want to live.  They now live in a caring and safe environment and their basic needs are well cared for.  This project can add another dimension to those lives, an outlet for their creativity and help build their self worth.   Have a look at the update Suzanne posted on YouTube and I am sure you will be as moved as I was by this woman's story.

Suzanne is an orphan herself and was taken to England by a group of English nurses and adopted by an English family after the Vietnam War.  She has now come back to Vietnam to help other orphans.

Please help me to help Suzanne and the Orphans of Allambie

What We Need & What You Get

I want to raise $7,180 to:

  • Buy camera equipment ($2,000)
  • Buy Photography Software (Lightroom / Photoshop - $120 / year)
  • Buy a Website for the orphanage to sell their photographs ($300 / year)
  • Sponsor an Orphan (A$660 / year)
  • Buy a computer and equipment specifically for photography ($2,500)
  • Field Trips for the Orphans ($400)
  • Living expenses whilst I am in Vietnam ($150 / week for 8 weeks = $1,200)

If I don't reach my goal of $7,180, anything you can donate will be greatly appreciated as I will have to fund the balance myself and I may not be able to provide the level of help I would like to.

Every contributor will receive a weekly update on the progress of the orphans via my Blog.  All contributors will receive photographs from the orphans themselves and depending on the contribution, that may be blog, digital or print form.

There are 5 perks to sponsor an orphan for a full twelve months. These sponsorships are essential to allow Suzanne to maintain Allambie.

Some contributors will receive an Allambie T Shirt.

The Impact

I have never done this before, but I have been in business for over 30 years, I have been a photographer for over 20 years and I believe I can help make a difference in these people's lives and you can too!

  • Help make a difference in an Orphan's life
  • Keep in touch with these wonderful people through their photography
  • Help build the self esteem of people who have had a really hard life
  • Help ease the strain off Suzanne, who funds this completely on her own and with donations from people like us.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please share this campaign on Facebook, Google Plus, Twitter and all the other Social Media Sites you can.
  • Invite your friends and family to help with this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Summary

This little church in Fredericksburg, Texas was once a place of faith and hope for local Black families, beginning in the 1870s. The church was eventually abandoned, but Black family descendants and local advocates and city authorities are working together to ensure it is protected, preserved and memorialized for its place in history.

What We Need

Much has been accomplished, but there is still much to be done to preserve the church and make it available for all people to comfortably attend services and even marry in this storied church.

A descendant of a Black family who attended services in the church, Gary Hunter is a paralegal by trade, and he is leading the restoration, The church is a 501C3 organization, and all gifts to its restoration are tax deductible.

The Impact

Local German settlers want the Church restored for the high regard many German families have for the Black families who built and attended services in this old church. It should be known that many Fredericksburg German settlers did not believe in slavery and sided with the Union during the Civil War, There is also a sense of home that Black families feel for Fredericksburg, as seen in their efforts to restore the church. This church was one of their first assets, as a people, and it was a symbol of local racial tolerance and the American dream. Possibly, the greatest impact of this campaign is the realization of how far we have come as a community and as a nation since segregation persisted over so many years.

Risks & Challenges

The greatest challenge is securing the funds for the materials and professional services to ensure the church stands strong and open to others for the current and future generations.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask others to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Like, Share and Comment to friends and family about this campaign.
  • Send notes to Gary, Paul and Bernardo to show your support and encouragement....  and share similar stories.

story:
My Story:

I am a Spanish professor and photographer from San Diego, CA. I will be leading a month long photography workshop for youth at Casa Amarela (Yellow House) in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. My vision for this 100cameras Snapshot Project is to see local youth learn photography and engage in creative expression as a means to grow both personally and professionally in the neighborhood of Morro da Providência, a favela in Rio. I have a deep passion for photography, teaching, and Brazilian culture. I have lived and worked in Brazil as a volunteer for extended periods of time, and I have also taught Spanish at the university level for over fifteen years. I have already spent time in the Providência neighborhood in Rio, and I recently had a photo exhibition showcasing these photos. I am hoping to give back to the community through the 100cameras project in order for the kids to grow creatively and personally.

 

 

The Project:

I was privileged to spend time in Rio de Janeiro with photographer and human rights activist Maurício Hora (when I did a workshop with Magnum photographer David Alan Harvey during the spring of 2014). While I was at Morro da Providência, I was impressed by Maurício Hora and the way he connected with and cared for the kids at Casa Amarela (a community center for youth donated by the French artist JR in 2009). In 2008, JR did a project in Providência called Women are Heroes (to celebrate the women in the neighborhood and also raise awareness about the demolition of houses and people being removed from their homes). In a gesture to help the community and specifically youth through art projects and educational activities, JR founded Casa Amarela for local kids to have a place to take interactive art classes, read books in a library, and also act as an activity center. I especially like how the community focus at Casa Amarela is specifically for the youth of the neighborhood, and this has been its purpose since it was started. I will come alongside both 100cameras and CoFondation (JR’s non-profit) in a collaboration to lead a workshop in Morro da Providência in which the kids in the neighborhood can learn about photography and visual storytelling, and also give back to their own community. Since I have experience with photography, teaching, and I also speak fluent Portuguese, I feel that I have some of the foundational elements to help create a meaningful project. I look forward to organizing, teaching classes, and offering a celebration of art and wholeheartedly dignifying the children and their potential during this project. This Snapshot project has the potential to have a profound effect on the kids’ lives and futures.

While I personally have covered many of the costs for this project, I still need your help! Would you consider donating to this wonderful cause? I am a volunteer, the people who lead both 100cameras and CoFondation volunteer their time for the projects they do. Your donation and support will help the kids at Casa Amarela have an amazing, life-changing experience! Please consider helping and sharing this cause with others!

100cameras:

100cameras is a non-profit organization based in New York City, and has successfully completed photography projects with youth around the world. The ultimate goal of 100cameras is to return all the proceeds that are collected through sales of photographs by youth participants to the communities where the projects take place. The Snapshot Project platform is a unique and custom-built model that equips passionate people to teach self-expression to kids worldwide. By bundling up everything that 100cameras has created and learned from the field, the Snapshot Project Platform kit puts the opportunity to teach and empower students directly into the hands of a Snapshot Project Leader. As the Snapshot Project Leader for Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, I will live, breathe, and thrive in facilitating a project in a community that I am passionate about and am committed to. The proceeds raised from the kids’ photos in Rio will go directly back to Morro da Providência and Casa Amarela educational projects in the future. This is a win-win combination, for sure! Contributions: Your contribution will help fund this project to empower Brazilian youth in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil!

Contributions will help cover the following costs:

1 Projector: $150

Computer: Snapshot Project Leader will provide $0

10 Student Binders: $30

Digital Cameras: $1000 (for 10 cameras @ $100 each) $1000

Memory Cards for 10 Cameras: $150

Journals (Composition Notebooks), Pens, and Art Supplies: $40

Printing for course materials: $30

Printing/Paper for photography during project: $100

Photography Exhibition in Rio de Janeiro: $150

Living/Housing for Snapshot Project Leader for four weeks: $500

Flight/Transportation for Snapshot Project leader: covered by SPL $0

Campaign Costs: production costs for perks, plus crowdfunding fees: $350                                         

Total: $2,500

 

Perks and donation levels:

$10 Donation – You will be rewarded with a unique Digital Download of a photo taken by a workshop participant. This is great for desktops or screensavers, and you will also get a personal thank you on Twitter.

$25 Donation – You will be rewarded with a unique 5 x 7 photographic print taken by a workshop participant. You will also get a personal thank you on Twitter.

$50 Donation – You will be rewarded with a unique 8 x 10 photographic print taken by a workshop participant. You will also get a personal thank you on Twitter.

$100 Donation – You will be rewarded with one 8 x 10 photographic print of your choice taken by a workshop participant. You will also get a personal thank you on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram.

$250 Donation – You will be rewarded with one 11 x 14 photographic print of your choice taken by a workshop participant. You will also get a personal thank you on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram and a chance to Skype or Facetime with class participants in Brazil!

$500 Donation – You will be rewarded with one 11 x 14 photographic print of your choice taken by a workshop participant, including a personal caption accompanying the print. You will also get a personal thank you on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram and a chance to Skype or Facetime with class participants in Brazil! For this level, you will also get one of my own 12 x 18 personal prints from my time in Brazil!

An important note: contributions are given directly to the Snapshot Project Leader to cover the costs exactly as outlined and are not going directly to the organization 100cameras. Also, the perks as promised will be fulfilled by the SPL and not through 100cameras.

 

 

Other ways to contribute:

Sharing the story and mission of my 100cameras Snapshot Project in Brazil is a wonderful way to support art, photography, learning, and a chance for the kids from Morro da Providência to have an amazing workshop over four weeks!

Ways to share:

Forward this campaign to friends and family by email Share this campaign through social media networks including Facebook, Instagram, Google Plus, Twitter, and LinkedIn etc. by copying and pasting the URL. Talk with your friends, colleagues, and family...and to anyone you know who loves photography, art, education, and giving children an amazing workshop!

Thanks again for any support that you can offer! Although monetary donations will help the project become a reality, I would love to keep in touch with you through social media as well. Follow along, and become a part of the journey!

Instagram: @scottmbennett    Twitter: @scottmbennett #100camerasSnapshotRio   #100camerasSnapshot
story_txt:
My Story: 
I am a Spanish professor and photographer from San Diego, CA. I will be leading a month long photography workshop for youth at Casa Amarela (Yellow House) in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. My vision for this 100cameras Snapshot Project is to see local youth learn photography and engage in creative expression as a means to grow both personally and professionally in the neighborhood of Morro da Providência, a favela in Rio. I have a deep passion for photography, teaching, and Brazilian culture. I have lived and worked in Brazil as a volunteer for extended periods of time, and I have also taught Spanish at the university level for over fifteen years. I have already spent time in the Providência neighborhood in Rio, and I recently had a photo exhibition showcasing these photos. I am hoping to give back to the community through the 100cameras project in order for the kids to grow creatively and personally.
 

 
The Project:
I was privileged to spend time in Rio de Janeiro with photographer and human rights activist Maurício Hora (when I did a workshop with Magnum photographer David Alan Harvey during the spring of 2014). While I was at Morro da Providência, I was impressed by Maurício Hora and the way he connected with and cared for the kids at Casa Amarela (a community center for youth donated by the French artist JR in 2009). In 2008, JR did a project in Providência called Women are Heroes (to celebrate the women in the neighborhood and also raise awareness about the demolition of houses and people being removed from their homes). In a gesture to help the community and specifically youth through art projects and educational activities, JR founded Casa Amarela for local kids to have a place to take interactive art classes, read books in a library, and also act as an activity center. I especially like how the community focus at Casa Amarela is specifically for the youth of the neighborhood, and this has been its purpose since it was started. I will come alongside both 100cameras and CoFondation (JR’s non-profit) in a collaboration to lead a workshop in Morro da Providência in which the kids in the neighborhood can learn about photography and visual storytelling, and also give back to their own community. Since I have experience with photography, teaching, and I also speak fluent Portuguese, I feel that I have some of the foundational elements to help create a meaningful project. I look forward to organizing, teaching classes, and offering a celebration of art and wholeheartedly dignifying the children and their potential during this project. This Snapshot project has the potential to have a profound effect on the kids’ lives and futures.
While I personally have covered many of the costs for this project, I still need your help! Would you consider donating to this wonderful cause? I am a volunteer, the people who lead both 100cameras and CoFondation volunteer their time for the projects they do. Your donation and support will help the kids at Casa Amarela have an amazing, life-changing experience! Please consider helping and sharing this cause with others!

story:
Hey, I'm Lucia and this is my story.

 

Today our nature is in danger, and climate change is dangerously threatening the most cold regions of the planet. When you see the Arctic on TV, its frozen seas and vast expanses of ice and snow look like they belong on another planet. But the damage climate change is causing to the region could have catastrophic consequences much closer to home.

  • >10% - rate at which summer sea ice is disappearing per decade, threatening species like polar bears
  • ¼ - estimated proportion of the world’s untapped oil and gas reserves found in the Arctic. As the ice moves out, oil companies are moving in.
  • 25,000 – polar bears in the wild today

As a Landscape Photographer and nature-lover I cannot stay in my Southern European comfort zone and watch our world disappear little by little. This is why I have decided to travel to the western most land of Europe, to Tasiilaq in the south-east of Greenland adventure.

This summer, 2017, I’ll leave for this solo at 37 years old I'm taking a risk to step out of everyday life, while I follow this dream and accomplish something both scary and exciting. My goal is for this expedition to spread awareness, a message of hope, and ultimately to sensitise people to take positive actions for themselves and for our planet - and to understand that they might be one and the same.

________________________________________________________
 

The Expedition

My expedition will take place in two different times, the first one this summer and will last 1 month, were I'll encounter my guide Robert Peroni and the Inuit people for the first time. I'll be able to travel with hunters and explore Greenland inside land.

I'll then come back during winter for another month, where I'll be immerse in the polar nights, while daylight is absent and the snow covers everything.

The expedition's aim is to photograph landscapes and people, while living with locals and getting to know them through both formal interviews and everyday life.

 

________________________________________________________
 

The Impact

You can join me in this mission by investing funds into the project! 

You'll be able to follow my adventures on my social networks, watching my videos and reading my daily blog. But not only, you can bring a piece of this Greenland adventure with the printed book that will collect my best photographs and stories. If you desire you can also join me in the two events that will be organised between the expeditions and at the end of it; where pictures will be exposed and stories will be told.

________________________________________________________

How will the funds be used?

All the money raised will be used for the expedition, for travelling, printing & shipping the book, for the prints and for helping the Arctic thanks to WWF (10% for the Planet).

What if I raise up more money? More money = More Budget to take actions! If I have more money than needed for both expeditions, then I'll be able to take more actions aiming to preserving the beauty of the Arctic! 

Contact Me

If you have any questions, don't hesitate to ask me via my email: contact@lucia.photo or leave a comment here on Indiegogo campaign page.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you undoubtedly would not like to, or are not able to contribute financially. That's fine! If you like what I'm doing here, perhaps you can help in other ways?

  1. Email people you think would find this expedition interesting!
  2. Share this campaign on social media using the Indiegogo share buttons!
  3. I will be grateful if you join me on this journey.You can follow me on Facebook  and Instagram

Thank you so MUCH!

story:
An inspirational large-format book of photographic images and words, sharing the experience of our forthcoming adventure into one of the world’s most awe-inspiring wild places. We are supporting SOS Children's Villages, Leh and Dharamsala, to care for and educate Tibetan Refugee Orphans.

Here's a brief on the project from my orientaleye.co.uk website

'This summer ,2013, I will be returning to Ladakh, high in the Himalayan Mountains, near to Tibet, for two months, with a special project in mind.
I will be travelling for 10 weeks with my photographer friend 'daffy', by motorcycle (50's classic Enfields) and Horseback, trekking too, through some of the most awe-inspiring landscapes on this beautiful planet. 
We will produce a boook which not only contains beautiful images and written word too, but will also illustrate our efforts, choices and decisions in the process of the adventure. Some of the images will, unusually, portray the photographer at work, with an explanation of all that was involved to make the shot - the DNA of the shot if you like. Also included will be the 'exif info' the camera and lens settings, which may help developing photographers (pun intended!) to understand the effects of different technical choices.
It won't be a technical manual, nothing like it, but I do think that some understanding of the whole story of the shots enables one to connect with and to 'feel' the shots a little more.
Funds raised through the project will help to support Tibetan Refugee Orphans'

Who are we?

 Dave Davies, builder, photographer & student of philosophy & psychology at The Open University, UK

&

Irwin ‘Daffy’ Smith, builder, photographer, musician.

‘’The call of the wild; that wondering of what lies beyond the horizon, that inner voice urging to venture where few others will go…listen…’’

Often-times our own sense of presence in this life is subdued…dormant almost, but there are places on this Earth that somehow, through sheer majestic beauty, bring forth a feeling of overwhelming wonder and amazement – and a deep sense of connection. Our hope is to capture this feeling by venturing high into the challenging and magnificent landscape of Ladakh, and to share the experience through photography and words. We are particularly interested in the idea of introducing the work of the photographer to you, the adventure of the project, the choices and decisions we make and to experiment with incorporating this into some of the shots, hopefully it'll make the work more enjoyable, more accessible and perhaps a little instructive too.

High in the Himalayas, in the far north of India, Ladakh is one of Earth's most isolated and remote regions, culturally rooted more in Tibet than India. Over two months in summer 2013, we plan to explore this region by motorcycle, pony and on foot.

 

There is a special urgency to the project - recently work has begun on the construction of a road tunnel through the Rohtang Pass, to open up access to the region, and the rail network is expanding northwards. The isolated uniqueness of the region may soon be diminished, and with it the opportunity for the adventurer to experience such a wilderness.

Rivers run deep, mountains climb high

Join us as we travel by motorcycle along the challenging and awe-inspiring Manali-Leh highway…over dangerous Rohtang La, the “Pile of Dead Bodies Pass”...up into the high Himalayan mountains and valleys… traversing ancient trade routes and gorges on horseback and by foot... staying with local people in remote communities and camping out beneath expansive crystal skies. Via camera and journal we will be recording both the awe-inspiring and the intimate moments as we face the hazards and joys of high altitude, avalanches, hairpin bends and vertical drops, fast flowing melt-water floods, local beer and... who knows...? 

Through your contribution and engagement with us on this project and through our regular photographic and written updates on our Facebook page we hope to transport you to the heart-place of our adventures as the on-going development of the project and book. This is a call to the spirit of all who realise the value of this life, of living it well and of its host, our planet Earth.

SOS Children’s Villages – our chosen charity

http://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/Pages/default.aspx

Our funding target includes the raising of a donation to SOS Children’s Villages – a worldwide charity with a marvellous record for supporting orphaned children with food, accommodation, health, pastoral care and education. In particular this money will go to the children’s facilities in Dharamsala, currently home to the Dalai Lama and also to the village near to Leh, Ladakh. Many Tibetan children have lost their parents during their dangerous escape from the Chinese occupation of Tibet and we hope to offer both financial as well as moral support to the organisation and to the children themselves.

We have set ourselves a tight budget. Your support will contribute to the costs of travel, motorcycle and pony hire, basic accommodation costs, a guide where it is unsafe to travel without such support, insurance, a contribution to the production costs of the first run of books and the delivery of perks to our donors, as well as, importantly, a generous donation to the Childrens Village Charity.

After our return, having completed our pledges this project will end.  However the passion to explore, to experience and to protect does not! We will also produce a collection of prints for sale in organised gallery showings, photographic society exhibitions, etc. and for sale via the internet, in order to contribute to our next planned project, 'Africa's Vanishing Tribes'.

We hope that you see value in this effort to celebrate the precious resource and majestic beauty that is at the heart of our wilderness and remote areas. It is the same presence, the same force, the same beauty that lies within our very own selves!

In order to succeed in our endeavours, to share experiences and images with you, we need your support. If you are moved to contribute to the project, thank you, your involvement is highly valued.

We are offering fantastic inducements & rewards commensurate with the level of support. Let us all keep our inspiration alive, to meet ourselves out on the edges…and remember that we carry that capacity for connection within. 

So, please keep up via the updates and comments sections of this project page and SHARE this link

Indiegogo have some pretty cool ‘sharing’ tools…It’d be a great help if you would use them to help us get the word out…it also ups our ranking in the popularity stakes and gets us more exposure from the indiegogo team!

Summary of Project Aims

  • Produce a book of outstanding quality about this ancient Himalayan Kingdom.
  • Show the human element in our work, thus allowing you to connect with and to fully enjoy what we do.
  • Highlight the threat to wilderness areas whilst acknowledging people’s right to adventuring and enjoyment of these areas
  • Support Tibetan Orphans as well as the work of SOS Children’s Villages charity organisation worldwide.
  • To use this project as a financial and awareness ‘springboard’ for our next photographic projects.

 

 

 Thank you for your support - Don't forget to scroll through the 'Perks' section to see what we can offer you in return. When you get to the 'Contribute' page don't forget to select a perk appropriate to your level of support.

 Thank you for your support - Don't forget to scroll through the 'Perks' section to see what we can offer you in return. When you get to the 'Contribute' page don't forget to select a perk appropriate to your level of support.

story:
Who the hell is Ivana?

I'm a struggling artist and college student with all of the debt and mediocre credit that comes with it. I'm interested in art, traveling, pop culture, animals, and documenting these things through photography.
 
I've studied photography in school for five years and have been taking pictures since I was old enough to hold a camera.
 

What good will this do anyway?

This campaign will help me raise the funds needed to fix my current photo equipment which has recently become unreliable and hard to use. If successful, the campaign will also enable me to buy upgraded equipment which will provide the tools needed for furthering my photographic skills. 

New equipment would allow for: Higher resolution images and better lighting (great for sharper pictures and large prints!), high speed and continuous shooting (good for important events or hyper kids!), and so many more options for artistic expression and learning! 

 

What's in it for you?

Perks! Choose a donation level and get stuff in return, from my gratitude and e-mail updates to posters or even wedding packages! I don't expect you to help me without getting something in return, so look through the options on the right and find something that interests you.
 
For clarification, I'd like to note that photoshoots and wedding packages paid for through this Indiegogo campaign will actually get you a voucher you can use to pay for those services at the time. This way you are protected in case your plans/dates/locations change. The voucher will have no expiration and be good for the specific services listed (rather than a specific price) OR for other services worth up to the price paid. Therefore you will be guaranteed no extra costs for change of date/venue, OR you could choose a replacement of any other service I offer (valid up to the price you paid) in the event your plans for the original package selected change.
 

Can't afford to contribute but still like to see more of my work?

No problem! You can still access my photos at several places around the web.


Website: www.AnaviNoslo.com

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AnaviNoslo

Twitter: https://twitter.com/iophotography

Tumblr: http://io-photography.tumblr.com

 

I also run a blog on how to make the best of your photography with a basic camera and every day items: http://shutterpunks.tumblr.com

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way you can help me with this campaign, whether you were able to contribute or not, would be to tell your friends. Share the link! Use the share tools located above this message and below the photos! Get the word out! That's a lot of exclamation points for me, so you know I'm serious!

story:
Begging on the Internet? No fun. But it’s come to this.

I’m a photo-memoirist-or-something-crazy-like-that, who has produced two books, one, “Flame Spirals” as a P.O.D., and the second, a fine-art quality lithography book through a local Tucson printer, called “Hoop Dancing.” Lithography is much superior to Print-On-Demand, but it is expensive. My last books were under 100 pages and financially manageable to me, but “The Transpersonal Papers: 1861-2010” is coming in at 200 plus pages. The cost of printing 200 to 300 limited edition copies of this book runs between $9,000 to $12,000. Yikes. I am a pretty well known nocturnal photographer and writer (or at least in my own zip-code) and I’m not just some egomanical artist who thinks what I do is SO important, but I am driven, and I do hope to bring a little healing and magic into the World. (OK, my ego is pretty big, but I do try to be a good and giving man.) I’m not broke but I’m not rich. And I could use your help.

That’s it. Just an artist who could use a little coin.

Needless to say, all who donate funds will be mentioned in the Acknowledgment pages of ‘The Transpersonal Papers" and I will think good and loving thoughts about all of you, for many months to come. Donate what you can. It really is a pretty special book, about everything from The Apache Wars in Southeastern Arizona over 100 years ago, and the Standing Stones of Callanish in Scotland, to the Flame Spirals I drew in the desert last month, and my mother’s dying of dementia, right here and right now.

Finally, thanks for reading this and give if you can. I could really use the help.

Love and light, Stu Jenks.

story:
This limited edition book is long gone, but you can still get prints by visiting the print shop here:

www.etsy.com/shop/MWphotographic



It's ALIVE! 


Prints!

The Prints have arrived! They look spectacular. The 5x7's should be going out soon. The 8x10s and 11x14's will ship with the books. 


WE MADE IT!  

WOW! Our fundraiser for "Northbound" has reached it's $7,500 goal! I wanted to extend a massive THANK YOU to everyone who contributed and help spread the word. 

How You Can Contribute And Get Your Own Book

This campaign will be your only opportunity to purchase a limited edition copy of Northbound. 

You can donate using your paypal account. If you do not have a paypal account that is just fine, you can "Pay as guest" at the check out page with your credit card. The perks you will receive are available on the right hand side of this page in the gray boxes. 

$7,500 is needed to get the production of this book off the ground. If the goal of $7,500 is not met you will be refunded your money in full. The only thing you'll lose is this awesome book.

The book and prints will be shipped by the end of February 2014. If you decide on a "prints only" package, from the right, they will ship independently from the books around the end of January. 

Domestic shipping is included on all levels of contributions. There will be an additional shipping charge on international orders of $15 for books, and $5 for the 5x7 print package.

A Bit About This Book

There was a moment on a mountaintop in Georgia, when I decided to look left instead of straight ahead. I saw an incredible landscape; a wilderness stretching for hundreds of miles. I followed the line of tree tops back from the horizon, tracing the curve of rock up to my own two feet. And then, to the people standing beside me.

I saw in their eyes the same view I had seen, but reflected in their own experience. We were all looking at the same thing, but each of us was seeing something different. It was in that moment that I knew the Appalachian Trail wasn't just about craggy mountains, deep valleys and beautiful vistas. It was about the sweat, the laughter, the sore bodies, and the bright eyes of ordinary people who had decided to do an extraordinary thing. 

The Appalachian Trail, AT for short, stretches nearly 2,200 miles from Springer Mountain in Georgia to Mount Katahdin in Maine, traversing the entire Appalachian mountain range across 14 states up the Eastern seaboard. In March of 2013, after coming to grips with the fact that we would be stinky and sore for 6 months, my wife Kit and I headed out into the wilderness to survive, enjoy, and endure, and to breathe real air from the shoulders of giants.

As a photographer, I began with the intent of documenting our journey to its fullest. It took less than a week for me to realize that hiking the Appalachian Trail was so much more than reconnecting with nature. I started hearing the AT referred to as a "The People's Trail" which truly resonated with me. It became clear that what I was most interested in on the trail were the people; their adventures, mishaps and triumphs. I never grew tired of the landscapes, the views, the cleanest air and the most refreshing water, but the whole time I remained most fascinated with my fellow hikers. 

I sought to capture in my photos how an unchanging landscape can instill deep change in the individuals who dare to explore it. This is why I chose to name the book Northbound. We were bound together as a community not only through our shared direction, but also through our common experience.

I have put together this book containing over 100 full color images of the people and the places those people explored. This is like no other book of photography I have seen documenting the Appalachian Trail. Other books have beautifully captured the physical nature of the trail and the landscape it moves through. The scenes captured are often inspiring and moving. Yet they somehow miss the true spirit of the trail, a place where strangers reach out to each other and judgments are held in abeyance. Here, all are equal; all are free; and all have their own reasons for starting, continuing, and finishing their journey. The most beautiful, inspiring, and moving scenes on the AppalachianTrail are of those traveling it.

Should you have any questions please email me at Michael @mwphotographic.com

If you'd like to see other work of mine please visit my website or blog.

What I Need To Make This Book A Reality

My goal is to print a limited edition book, titled Northbound. This 112 page book will be 12"x9" filled with well over a hundred full color photographs from the Appalachian Trail. This is a limited edition book and will not have a print run larger than 500 copies. In order for this to succeed I will need to raise at least $7,500. This amount will be used to print the first 100 copies, anything raised over this amount will go into expanding the edition, but no more than 500 copies will ever be printed. The money raised will go entirely to the production and shipping costs related to this book. I am working with a book publishing company in The United States, to ensure printing of this book is truly American made. I am very committed to having a great book printed for you. The goal of excellent color printing, professional binding, and a hand crafted cover comes at a cost. What I truly want is for you to love this book as much as I do. 

If you would you like a detailed breakdown of all the cost entailed in the manufacturing of this book please email me at Michael@mwphotographic.com I am more that happy to share the numbers with you. 

Image options for print perks:

Below are 5 images to choose 3 of for prints mentioned in the contribution perks. Please specify which prints you would like from below. If your contribution perk mentions choosing a 16x22 print from the book, you may select that print after you have received your copy of Northbound, and I will make sure you receive your chosen print. All photographs are printed on Kodak Professional Supra Endura Paper, allowing for excellent color reproduction and a beautiful semi-matte finish. 

1.

2.

3.

4.

5.

Other Ways You Can Help

I fully realize some people may not be able to help fund Northbound. That doesn't mean you still can't help. It would be just as helpful to share this project with friends or family. You can share this project through Facebook, emails, phone calls or my favorite, accompanied with hug.

Music by Eluvium, "Radio Ballet" https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/radio-ballet/id319144519?i=319144558

story:
The Project

Obsolete and Discontinued explores the diversity of analogue photography through a collection of discarded photographic materials. In March 2015, I was given a quantity of outdated photographic paper from the darkroom of the late Bret Sampson, artist and teacher. Numerous boxes and packets, the majority of which had ceased production years ago. Most were 20 to 30 years old, some far older. Given that this material had been stored for so long, it was a welcome surprise that after testing, some encouraging results were produced. Many papers seemed unusable and degraded with conventional photographic processes but responded well to more specialist and alternative techniques. 

Andrew Whittle

I then wondered what others could do with this material and appealed to a wider community of photographers and artists to accept the challenge to produce original and creative work using this paper. It was distributed to over 60 participants, purposely with an open brief, so was up to each photographer to consider how to use their selected material. Over a period of months, prints were returned using a wide variety of processes including silver gelatin, lith printing, wet collodion, paper negative and several hybrid analogue/digital techniques.

https://obsolete-discontinued.com

Almudena Romero

Exhibitions

Obsolete and Discontinued was launched in May 2016, at the Revela-T festival of photography in Vilassar de Dalt, Catalonia, Spain. It has subsequently been exhibited in November 2016 at Schaelpic Photokunstbar in Cologne Germany and will next be shown in London in October 2018 at Waterstones Bookshop Gallery, Gower Street, W1.

Brian Griffin

The participants 

Joakim Ahnfelt, Andrew Atkinson, Laurie Baggett, Myka Baum, Molly Behagg, Daniel Berrange, Andy Billington, David Bruce, Jacquelene Butler, Andrew Chisholm, Mike Crawford, Beth Dow, Angela Easterling, Laura Ellenberger, Joachim Falck-Hansen, Andrew Firth, Brittonie Fletcher, Hannah Fletcher, Asya Gefter, Claus Dieter Geissler, Robin Gillanders, Brian Griffin, JJ Hastings, Rosie Holtom, Tobias D Kern, Melanie King, Morten Kolve, Andrej Lamut, Ky Lewis, James Lister, Constanza Isaza Martinez, Nicola Jayne Maskrey, Hiro Matsuoka, Gabriela Mazowiecka, Sheila McKinney, Wolfgang Moersch, Peter Moseley, Helen Nias, Douglas Nicolson, Yaz Norris, Andres Pantoja, Guy Patterson, Borut Peterlin, Almudena Romero, Tina Rowe, Debbie Sears, Holly Shackleton, Keith Taylor, Joan Teixidor, Evan Thomas, Madaleine Trigg, Sebnem Ugural, Tanja Verlak, Anna C Wagner, Andrew Whittle, Guillame Zuili.

Yaz Norris

The Book

The book has been designed by Paul McKenzie Studio and will soon be going to print so will be ready to send to backers towards the end of September. The official launch will be at the opening of the London exhibition at Waterstones Bookshop, Gower Street, WC1. It will feature a full portfolio of the project, showcasing the diversity of the work with an introductory essay by Brigitte Lardinois.

Tanja Velak

 

Book Details

Edited by Mike Crawford

Designed by Paul McKenzie Studio

Introductory essay by Brigitte Lardinois

Cloth bound hardback, 128 pp

Size: 28x24cm

Published by Brovira Press

Printed by GTS Slovenia

ISBN: 978-1-9164507-0-7

Edition: 750 copies

Joachim Falck-Hansen

Limited Edition Prints

Through Indiegogo, we are issuing eight editions of eight prints from the project. They are available with a copy of the book for £150.

Print size: 9.5 x 12", Signed and numbered, in protective archival sleeve and presentation box.

Archival inkjet prints on Fotospeed Platinum Baryta 300gsm. 

 

Available Prints:

 

Tina Rowe

Almudena Romero

Andres Pantoja

Constanza Isaza Martinez

Melanie King

Asya Gefter

Brittonie Fletcher

Mike Crawford

story:
Support An Early Career Journalist

Hi, my name is Kimberly and I am about to embark on my first reporting trip abroad. I've been a journalist for just over a year and have had photography and illustration in such publications as the Playboy, Foreign Policy, the Seattle Globalist and small town newspapers in Western Washington. 

As of right now, a colleague and myself will be in the Middle East reporting together and separately on different issues impacting the region. I will be reporting on the effects of drought and pollution on agriculture and water security in Northern Iraq, as well as other climate change and environmental issues as I come upon them.

It has always been my greatest dream to report from the Middle East and now I have finally been given the opportunity.

What I Need & What You Get

As any freelance photographer and/or writer will tell, finances can get tight. I maintain another job, but given I need to cover some expenses for the trip out of pocket while still paying bills, there isn't much room in my budget for additional camera gear.

What I need consists of:

  • An additional camera body
  • A telephoto lens
  • A point and shoot camera
  • A harness to accommodate two DSLRs
  • Lighting equipment
  • And (finances permitting) funds to fix my broken Minolta X-700 and 50mm lens to shoot film

The Impact

Now more than ever, we are in need of unbiased quality journalism and given the nature of the industry right now, not many of us are offered the support we need in order to do the quality of work our viewers and readers deserve.

Becoming a freelance journalist is easily one of the most difficult undertakings I have committed to in my life, but with devotion and passion, I am absolutely set on creating the best possible work I can and doing these issues the justice they need.

By supporting me, you not only help ensure that great journalism can continue, but are also helping a young female journalist break into the field.

No part of this is easy, but journalism is something I have devoted my whole heart to and I am earnestly committed to great success in the field.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there are other ways to support me in meeting my goals!

If you own old camera equipment you aren't using anymore, I will happily accept anything offered. 

Spreading the word is also very significant and can go a long way! 

And that's all there is to it.

I am grateful for any help that I receive and greatly appreciate all of you!
