It has always been my greatest dream to report from the Middle East and now I have finally been given the opportunity.

What I Need & What You Get
As any freelance photographer and/or writer will tell, finances can get tight. I maintain another job, but given I need to cover some expenses for the trip out of pocket while still paying bills, there isn't much room in my budget for additional camera gear.
What I need consists of:

An additional camera body
A telephoto lens
A point and shoot camera
A harness to accommodate two DSLRs
Lighting equipment
And (finances permitting) funds to fix my broken Minolta X-700 and 50mm lens to shoot film


The Impact
Now more than ever, we are in need of unbiased quality journalism and given the nature of the industry right now, not many of us are offered the support we need in order to do the quality of work our viewers and readers deserve.
Becoming a freelance journalist is easily one of the most difficult undertakings I have committed to in my life, but with devotion and passion, I am absolutely set on creating the best possible work I can and doing these issues the justice they need.
By supporting me, you not only help ensure that great journalism can continue, but are also helping a young female journalist break into the field.
No part of this is easy, but journalism is something I have devoted my whole heart to and I am earnestly committed to great success in the field.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't donate, there are other ways to support me in meeting my goals!
If you own old camera equipment you aren't using anymore, I will happily accept anything offered. 
Spreading the word is also very significant and can go a long way! 
And that's all there is to it.I am grateful for any help that I receive and greatly appreciate all of you!

story:
HAPPY 10 YEAR ANNIVERSARY TO THE FINEST!

So, it’s our 10 year anniversary!! Do not attempt to adjust your screens--we have taken over the airwaves and we're gonna kick it up a notch this year!!

The Finest: A G.I. Joe Costume Club is thrilled to again partner with K9s for Warriors for the FOURTH annual Girls of the Finest charity calendar! Over the last three years we have been able to donate more and more money to the various charities we've partnered with, and in doing so we've showed the world just how powerful the G.I. Joe fan community is when it comes to charities for veteran and military-related organizations.

YOU KNOW THE DEAL (and if you don’t, here it is):

The Girls of the Finest Charity Calendar is no ordinary 12-month calendar! Our amazing members are photographed exclusively for this calendar, while portraying many of your favorite G.I. Joe and Cobra characters!

In our charity efforts, we always strive to engage charity organizations that would help assist service men and women after they return home in an impactful way, as many Finest members are active duty service members and veterans.  Once again, it's the Finest's honor to partner with K9s For Warriors, a nonprofit organization dedicated to providing service canines to warriors suffering from Post-traumatic Stress Disability, traumatic brain injury and/or military sexual trauma as a result of military service post 9/11. 

Their goal is to empower veterans to return to civilian life with dignity and independence.  Ninety-five percent of the canines in the K9s For Warriors’ program come from rescue shelters, and in 2015, the organization was able to raise more than $5.5 million dollars, which allowed them to pair 51 Warriors with service dogs – that’s at least 102 lives saved because of each person’s contribution!  In September 2016, K9s for Warriors opened their second kennel, which houses up to 27 dogs in training; the 17,000 sq. ft. training facility now can house and train up to 54 dogs!  In May 2017, they trained and graduated their 300th warrior! They’re also diligently pushing the PAWS Act (Puppies Assisting Wounded Servicemembers), which would authorize a five-year, $10 million pilot program to provide trained canines to veterans with Post-traumatic Stress Disability.  We decided we wanted to help them reach their goal of helping 12 warriors each month, so ONE HUNDRED PERCENT of the net proceeds earned from the 2017 Girls of the Finest calendar will be donated to K9s for Warriors! 

What better way to come together as a fan community and support the Real American Heroes of the U.S. military and their families?

We Need YOU!

We can't do this without YOU! Only through your donations will this calendar happen. Your contribution of $5 or more will allow us to:

• Compile all the calendar photography

• Design and produce the calendar and all associated perks

• Pay for printing and shipping costs of the calendar and perks

As in previous years, we create EXCLUSIVE content for this campaign that will only be available to those who donate here, including Girls of the Finest trading cards, postcards, patches, t-shirts and NEW SURPRISE TIERS!!! Just like the last three years, these perks will only be produced in limited quantities and once they're gone, THEY’RE GONE! 

Everyone who donates $5 or more will receive exclusive Girls of The Finest item(s). Anyone donating $25 or more will receive the calendar PLUS exclusive items! (See perks on the right for a complete list)

* NOTE: We are happy to ship calendars and perks anywhere in the world! If you are in Canada, please add $7 to your donation to cover shipping. If you are outside North America, please email us your location and we will let you know what additional shipping charges may apply.

How to Get Involved

Donating funds is the #1 way to get involved, but if you can’t contribute financially, that doesn’t mean you can’t help! You can spread the word about our campaign! Share our link on Facebook, Twitter or other social media. Let other fandom groups know what we're doing and use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word. Harness the power of the Internet to help us achieve our goal with the K9s For Warriors! Get involved however you can - all help is appreciated!

The Impact You Make

The more funds we collect, the more funds go to K9s For Warriors and to the veterans and their families who need our help!  We want to be able to help out the men and women who sacrifice so much for us every single day. We value and appreciate their contributions and sacrifices and we want to show them how much they mean to us all.

This is a community call to action! Please join us, and together, let’s make a huge difference in the lives of military personnel and families!

Thank you!!!!!

story:
*A prototype is shown. Final product may slightly vary.

We did it again!
We just started new campaign, but with three changes:
1. Firstly, and the main, we found the way to print small run of the book. We chose Flexible Funding campaign with flexible goal. It's means that we keep all funds even if we do not meet the goal. And the book will be printed in any case (even if the campaign will not reach the goal).
2. Secondly, we changed the cover (we don't have a prototype of the cover so you can see a digital mockup)
3. And because to print a small edition is quite expensive, unfortunately the price of the book has increased .

Hi all,  

I am Ilya and I am from Russia. Me and my friends, we live in Moscow and we are into photography, graphic design and book design; apart from that, we have a collection of designer vinyl toys.  

Today we would like to present a project, which is unique for our country – an art book fully dedicated to designer collectibles. The book is a collection of fantastic photographs made by our good friend, one of the most well-known Russian toy collector and toy photographer Roman Shevchenko, aka AlPred on the net. 

Roman started collecting designer toys in 2009 and his collection had been growing bigger and bigger up to 2014. Within five years he created a unique collection featuring a lot of rare and exclusive action figures. Some of them were produced as a single copy and some were even custom made personally for Roman. 

Roman was an active member of the toy community; he visited fairs all around the world, talked to designers. He was so open, communicative and enthusiastic that he got along with everyone who had a chance to get to know him. He became quite well-known in the global toy community; so after he passed away in 2014, Coarsetoys released an action figure of Omen Fade as a tribute to him. We are grateful to the company founders Mark and Sven for granting us the right to use the sketch of Omen on our book cover. It is extremely important for us.    

Roman was the biggest contributor to the popularity of designer toys in Russia, largely thanks to his photographs. He did not just take photos of the action figures, every time he told a little story and introduced the figure from a very special, different angle. The figures were not just part of Roman’s collection, in his photos they came to life and acted as characters of lots of stories. His pictures always stirred interest and motivated the others not just to collect figures, but to be creative while doing it. 

This book contains photographs of toys by various designers, from mass produced figures by Ashley Wood and Coarse to single custom-made ones by Jon-Paul Kaiser and Squink.  

The book is truly valuable because many of the figures in it are rare or unique, it is not easy to find their photos even online. Moreover, the book is made up not just from standard catalogue shots, these are awesome pictures – at times funny, at times sad, at times gloomy, at times romantic, but never leaving the viewer indifferent. We also included in the book Romans ideas on collecting, photography and on his own collection.  

The following designers can be found in the book: Ashley Wood, Angry Woebots, Blamo Toys, Captain HH, Coarse, Ferg, Jon-Paul Kaiser, Kenny Wong, Luke Chueh, Michael Lau, Mr. Clement, Squink and many others.  

The main goal of our project is to treasure Roman’s memory, show and share his creative work with the public. Besides, we are hoping that the funds that we manage to collect will not only cover the printing, but will be enough to pass on to Roman’s family, his wife and children. 

At the moment the book has already been made up, a proof copy has been printed and we are ​gathering money to start printing the whole lot. 

Specs:

  • Text language: Russian and English 
  • Hardcover 
  • 21х26 cm (8.2 x 10.2 inches) 
  • 320 pages

Perk details:

​Choose your perk by selecting it from the right hand column at the top of the page.

  • $165   Hall of fame  (Hardcover Book + acknowledgement in the Book )  
  • $20     Many thanks!              
  • $65     Hardcover Book     
  • $130   Two Hardcover Books          
  • $195   Three Hardcover Books

Timeline:

  • July 6 – 23 – Indiegogo Campaign
  • August – Production and quality check
  • September – Start shipping

​

Other ways you can help:

If you can’t contribute financially, we completely understand. There a still other ways you can help! Share the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Snapchat and other. Or just copy-and-paste this page’s link and share in any way you wish! Don't forget to use our hashtag #alpredbook

We hope that you find this project interesting and worth being part of it!

Thank you!

Our team:

  • Maria Kaner - Art direction and design
  • Ilya Kaner - Production and design
  • and our friends who very helped

Or just copy-and-paste this page’s link and share in any way you wish! Don't forget to use our hashtag #alpredbookWe hope that you find this project interesting and worth being part of it!Thank you!Our team:

and our friends who very helped

story:
I'm a photographer and I'm having my debut exhibition of my abstract work. 
Space has been secured at my local library for up to 15 pieces. 

Part one  First Fundraiser raised enough for a few pieces to get printed and framed and ready to hang.This second fundraiser is so even more can be produced and fill the walls. Also it can allow for marketing materials, 


This is a large show and I have no inventory from prior shows, as this is my first!

Funding is needed for printing and framing and mounting of each piece.  

You can choose a perk for specific donation amounts and receive the gift that is described. 

The funding goal is the bare minimum for 5 pieces of various sizes. Funds recieved below the goal will be used to print whatever that amount will allow. Funding above the goal will give me the ability to show more pieces and perhaps print marketing materials for the show. 

As an artist, exposure like this can be invaluable. You will be helping me to get my work seen. 


There are no risks in fulfilling this project. If this project is successfully funded, the funds will go directly to funding the direct production of prints to be displayed at an exhibit I have already been accepted and scheduled for.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can always share this with others to help e get the word out.

You can use the Indiegogo share tools. Just click and share!

story:
My name is Brittany Forrest and I am a senior at Ithaca College. I am studying Cinema and Photography and currently am enrolled in the senior photography thesis class. I am hoping to raise money to fund my final exhibition as an undergrad. The exhibition is in December 2012.

My project is about the relationship between the natural and the man-made. I am interested in the interaction between these elements and the beauty they possess.My attempt is to create a connection and juxtaposition between different parts of the human environment and create an understanding of their complex relationship.

Estimated Expenses:

Printing Costs: 200.00

Finishing/Exhibition Costs: 400.00

Total: 600.00

Any amount you can donate would be greatly appreciated!

The smallest amount can make the biggest difference.

Please help by spreading the word and if able to, coming to the exhibition! (more details to follow)

Also I have some perks for different amounts of funding. Check it out!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Discrimination and Displacement

Kennedy Hill is an Aboriginal community that sits on pristine land overlooking the sea in Broome, a resort town on the north coast of Western Australia.  Though Aboriginal people have lived in Kennedy Hill for generations, the residents are now threatened with displacement as the result of a recent government declaration. 

Photojournalist Ingetje Tadros settled in Broome not far from the Mallingbarr Community, known to the locals as Kennedy Hill and because of a lifelong interest in the fate of indigenous people, became friends with many of the people living there.  Ingetje found people in distress, mistreated by their government, misunderstood by the aid community and largely invisible to Australian society: a voiceless and unseen community. She photographed her neighbours and friends and her images brought their story, This Is My Country,  to the world. 


A sweeping government policy of settlement closure and dissolution of Indigenous Australian communities is devastating people who live in them. The displacement policy creates a painful physical, emotional and spiritual disconnect from their sacred land. The Kimberley,Western Australia.

Kennedy Hill is not alone.  There are more than 100 indigenous communities threatened with displacement in Western Australia under the current government's mandate. This Is My Country  will stand as a permanent testament to  the commitment of these communities to endure, to resist displacement and to protect traditional settlements.

Romaine holds a white rabbit. He came with his family from the Wangkatjungka Community about 700 km's from Broome.  'We came to do some shopping' he said. One Mile Community, Broome, Western Australia.

This Is My Country went out as a plea to Australian society to hear the voice of their First People.  It was widely published in Australia (and by STERN in Germany) and received recognition worldwide with, among others,  the Walkley Award for Excellence in Photojournalism -Feature Photographic Essay- 2015 (the Australian equivalent of the Pulitzer Prize), the Amnesty International Media Awards 2015, photography, Best Feature Photographic Essay at the West Australian Media Awards 2015,  the Exposure Award, digital display at The Louvre in Paris 2015.

First meal of the day for this family consists of bacon, eggs and damper cooked inside a condemned building in the One Mile Community, just on the entrance to the tourism town of Broome. Western Australia.

The publication of This Is My Country will create a permanent record of and bring attention to the plight of Aboriginal communities under threat.  It will serve as a call to Australian society to support their First People and end the displacement of their communities. 

The Photographer 

This Is My Country looks at people standing on the precipice of life: disenfranchised, neglected and now threatened with displacement.

I moved to Australia twelve years ago and was deeply affected by what I saw. I set out to document the lives of Australia's indigenous people, travelling to remote regions of Australia’s vast and unforgiving outback to spend time in Aboriginal communities and witness their life on the margins. I heard and felt their discontent. I found communities fractured and in distress with high incidences of alcoholism, domestic violence and suicide. I saw that communities were mismanaged by their governments, not fully understood by the wider aid community and largely invisible to the remainder of Australian society.

I had the good fortune to live close to an Aboriginal community where I settled in Broome (a resort town by the sea on the north coast of Western Australia). Kennedy Hill, as it is called, lies on a beautiful piece of land overlooking the sea a short distance and on pristine real estate.

I feel strongly that the Aboriginal people are not treated with the respect they deserve as the First Peoples of this country. When you sit with the people and hear their stories it becomes obvious how beautiful these people are. Their connection with their land, their country and their family, is something we all can learn from.

Kennedy Hill is just one community that exists in the shadows of Western Australian Premier Colin Barnett’s commitment to close down approximately 100 - 150 Aboriginal communities in Western Australia. There are more than 270 remote Indigenous communities in Western Australia which is home to 12,000 people. Aboriginal Elders and Leaders are shocked and see the closing down of communities as a threat. 

A fight ensues next to where a homeless family sleeps on the ground. Kennedy Hill, Broome, Western Australia.


As confronting as some of my photographs are here, I hope that they will communicate the plight of the people in them. And act as a catalyst for debate and- and as an agent for social change – no matter how small.

The Book

This Is My Country will be a hard cover book of 112 pages with 70 black and white photographs and an introduction by aboriginal writer and film maker mitch torres. It will be printed in a hardbound edition on 170 gsm paper at Ofset Yapimevi in Istanbul where all of FotoEvidence's high quality books are produced.

By backing This Is My Country you will be part of creating an enduring document about the struggle for justice of Australia's First People and supporting Aboriginal communities as they fight displacement.

This Is My Country in the Sydney Morning Herald. 


Aboriginal people in the Kimberley have strong ties with the pastoralists who came in the 1800's and took over their land. Generations of Aboriginal stockworkers helped to build the white cattle industry. Wangkatjungka Community, Western Australia.

 

Follow Ingetje Tadros on Instagram:  Ingetje Tadros on Instagram

Visit Ingetje Tadros' Website: Ingetje Tadros website 

Connect with Ingetje Tadros on Linked In:  Ingetje Tadros at Linked In

remote regions of Australia’s vast and unforgiving outback to spend time in
Aboriginal communities and witness their life on the margins. I heard and felt
their discontent. I found communities fractured and in distress with high
incidences of alcoholism, domestic violence and suicide. I saw that communities
were mismanaged by their governments, not fully understood by the wider aid
community and largely invisible to the remainder of Australian society. 
I
had the good fortune to live close to an Aboriginal community where I settled
in Broome (a resort town by the sea on the north coast of Western Australia). Kennedy Hill, as it is called, lies on a beautiful piece of land
overlooking the sea a short distance and on pristine real estate.
I
feel strongly that the Aboriginal people are not treated with the respect they
deserve as the First Peoples of this country. When you sit with the people and
hear their stories it becomes obvious how beautiful these people are. Their
connection with their land, their country and their family, is something we all
can learn from.
Kennedy
Hill is just one community that exists in the shadows of Western Australian
Premier Colin Barnett’s commitment to close down approximately 100 - 150
Aboriginal communities in Western Australia. There are more than 270 remote
Indigenous communities in Western Australia which is home to 12,000
people. Aboriginal Elders and Leaders are shocked and see the closing down
of communities as a threat. 



A fight ensues next to where a homeless family sleeps on the ground. Kennedy Hill, Broome, Western Australia.

As confronting as some of my photographs are here, I hope that they will communicate the plight of the people in them. And act as a catalyst for debate and- and as an agent for social change – no matter how small.
The Book

This Is My Country will be a hard cover book of 112 pages with 70 black and white photographs and an introduction by aboriginal writer and film maker mitch torres. It will be printed in a hardbound edition on 170 gsm paper at Ofset Yapimevi in Istanbul where all of FotoEvidence's high quality books are produced.
By backing This Is My Country you will be part of creating an enduring document about the struggle for justice of Australia's First People and supporting Aboriginal communities as they fight displacement.
This Is My Country in the Sydney Morning Herald. 



Aboriginal people in the Kimberley have strong ties with the pastoralists who came in the 1800's and took over their land. Generations of Aboriginal stockworkers helped to build the white cattle industry. Wangkatjungka Community, Western Australia.
